Back (EN): Is there a lot of traffic?
Notes: Bogotá's most common traffic question | 'Trancón' is the Colombian word for traffic jam | Example: "¿Hay mucho trancón en la Autopista Norte?" = Is there a lot of traffic on Autopista Norte? | Informal

Front (ES): Duré una hora en el trancón
Back (EN): I was stuck in traffic for an hour
Notes: Common complaint in Bogotá and other Colombian cities | 'Durar' means to last/take time | Example: "Disculpa la demora, duré dos horas en el trancón" = Sorry for the delay, I was stuck in traffic for two hours | Informal
Alternative: Me quedé una hora en el trancón

Notes: Paisa (Medellín) expression for traffic jam | 'Taco' = traffic jam in Antioquia region | 'Berraco' = intense/crazy | Example: "Me pillé un taco en la avenida" = I got caught in a traffic jam on the avenue | Regional: Paisa | Informal

Back (EN): I got caught in a traffic jam
Notes: Paisa (Medellín) slang | 'Pillar' = to catch | Example: "Llegué tarde porque me pillé un taco en la Regional" = I arrived late because I got caught in a traffic jam on Regional highway | Regional: Paisa | Very informal

Traffic restriction system in major Colombian cities | Limits vehicles during rush hours based on license plate numbers | Example: "No puedo manejar hoy, tengo pico y placa de 6 a 8 AM" = I can't drive today, I have plate restrictions from 6 to 8 AM | Essential for navigating Colombian cities | Formal/Informal
Common excuse for not driving | Example: "¿Me pasas recogiendo? Hoy tengo pico y placa" = Can you pick me up? Today I have plate restrictions | Informal
Alternative: Hoy no puedo sacar el carro

Back (EN): I'm going to take the TransMilenio
Notes: Bogotá's BRT (Bus Rapid Transit) system | Most common public transport in Bogotá | Example: "Nos vemos en una hora, voy a tomar el Transmilenio" = See you in an hour, I'm taking the TransMilenio | Informal
Frequent complaint during rush hour | Example: "Llegué tarde porque el Transmilenio estaba llenísimo" = I arrived late because the TransMilenio was super packed | Informal

Back (EN): I'm going to take a SITP bus
Notes: SITP = Sistema Integrado de Transporte Público (Bogotá's integrated bus system) | Modern bus system in Bogotá | Example: "El SITP que coge es el azul" = The SITP you take is the blue one | Informal

Back (EN): Does any buseta pass by here?
Notes: Buseta = small bus (40-50 passenger capacity) | Traditional Colombian transport | Example: "¿Esta buseta va para el centro?" = Does this buseta go downtown? | Informal

Back (EN): I'm going to take the metro
Notes: Medellín's metro system (only metro in Colombia) | Example: "El metro de Medellín es muy eficiente" = Medellín's metro is very efficient | Informal | Note: 'coger' is acceptable in Colombia, unlike some Latin American countries

Medellín's cable car system integrated with metro | Connects barrios to city center | Example: "El Metrocable tiene unas vistas increíbles de la ciudad" = The Metrocable has incredible views of the city | Informal

Back (EN): I'm going to request an Uber
Notes: Despite legal ambiguity, Uber is widely used in Colombia | Example: "Pedí un Uber porque está lloviendo" = I requested an Uber because it's raining | Informal

Back (EN): The Uber is on its way
Notes: Common phrase when waiting for pickup | Example: "Tranquila, el Uber ya viene en 3 minutos" = Don't worry, the Uber is coming in 3 minutes | Informal
Uber verification code shared with driver | Example: "Es el carro gris? Dame el pin para confirmar" = Is it the gray car? Give me the PIN to confirm | Informal
Requesting taxi service | Yellow taxis are official in Colombia | Example: "¿Me puedes llamar un taxi para el aeropuerto?" = Can you call me a taxi to the airport? | Informal
Standard phrase for taxi | Example: "Voy a tomar un taxi para llegar más rápido" = I'm going to take a taxi to get there faster | Informal
Taxi driver's first question | Example: "A dónde va? - A la zona T" = Where are you going? - To Zona T | Informal/Formal
Asking taxi fare before getting in (especially for taxis without meter) | Example: "Cuánto cobra hasta el aeropurado?" = How much do you charge to the airport? | Informal

Back (EN): Drop me off at the corner
Notes: Common instruction to taxi driver | Example: "Déjeme en la esquina de la 85 con 15" = Drop me off at the corner of 85th and 15th | Informal/Formal
Telling taxi driver to stop | Example: "Aquí está bien, gracias" = Here is fine, thank you | Informal/Formal

Back (EN): I have to run some errands
Notes: 'Hacer vueltas' is the Colombian way to say 'run errands' | Very common expression | Example: "No puedo ahora, tengo que hacer unas vueltas en el banco" = I can't now, I have to run some errands at the bank | Informal
When you're currently doing errands | Example: "Te llamo después, ando en vueltas" = I'll call you later, I'm out running errands | Very informal
Slightly more formal than 'vueltas' but less common in everyday Colombian speech | Example: "Mañana tengo que hacer varias diligencias" = Tomorrow I have to do several errands | Formal/Informal
'Manejar' is used in Colombia (not 'conducir' like in Spain) | Example: "Voy a manejar hasta Medellín" = I'm going to drive to Medellín | Informal

Back (EN): Do you know how to drive?
Notes: Common question | Example: "Sabes manejar carro o solo moto?" = Do you know how to drive a car or just motorcycle? | Informal
'Parquear' is Colombian Spanish (from English 'to park') | Example: "¿Dónde parqueo el carro?" = Where do I park the car? | Informal | Note: Spain uses 'aparcar', but Colombia uses 'parquear'

Back (EN): I'm looking for a parking lot
Notes: 'Parqueadero' is Colombian word for parking lot | Example: "¿Hay un parqueadero cerca?" = Is there a parking lot nearby? | Informal
Common frustration in Colombian cities | Example: "Toca buscar otro parqueadero, este está lleno" = We have to find another parking lot, this one is full | Informal

Back (EN): I got a traffic camera ticket
Notes: 'Fotomulta' = automated traffic fine using cameras | Common in Bogotá and other cities | Example: "Me llegó una fotomulta por exceso de velocidad" = I got a camera ticket for speeding | Informal
'Arrancar' = to start/to leave | Very common Colombian expression | Example: "Ya es tarde, arranquemos" = It's already late, let's get going | Informal
Literal meaning of 'arrancar' (to start engine) | Example: "Arranca el carro que ya voy saliendo" = Start the car, I'm coming out now | Informal
Taxi drivers and service workers use this phrase | Example: Taxi driver shouts "A la orden!" to indicate they're available | Very Colombian | Informal/Formal

Back (EN): Watch out for the traffic / Be careful with traffic
Notes: 'Pilas' = be alert/careful | Very Colombian | Example: "Pilas con el tráfico que está pesado" = Watch out for the traffic, it's heavy | Informal
Common way to describe bad traffic | Example: "Mejor salimos temprano, el tráfico está muy pesado" = We better leave early, the traffic is very heavy | Informal
Bogotá's famous Sunday tradition where 120+ km of streets close to cars | Example: "Vamos a la ciclovía el domingo?" = Are you going to ciclovía on Sunday? | Informal | Cultural icon
Making plans for Sunday car-free streets event | Example: "Nos vemos en la ciclovía de la Séptima" = See you at the ciclovía on Séptima Avenue | Informal | Bogotá-specific
Used in buses, taxis, or cars | Example: "Señor, me bajo aquí en el semáforo" = Sir, I'm getting off here at the traffic light | Informal

Back (EN): Stop me at the traffic light
Notes: Common instruction to taxi/bus driver | Example: "Páreme en el próximo semáforo por favor" = Stop me at the next traffic light please | Informal/Formal
Indicating you're not driving | Example: "Puedo tomar hoy, voy de pasajero" = I can drink today, I'm going as a passenger | Informal

Back (EN): Step on it / Give it gas
Notes: Telling driver to speed up or go | Example: "Dale gas que vamos tarde" = Step on it, we're running late | Very informal
'Pico' can refer to peak/rush hour | Example: "Mejor nos vemos después del pico" = We better meet after rush hour | Informal | Note: different from 'pico y placa'

Back (EN): We got caught in an Uber
Notes: Reference to Uber's legal ambiguity in Colombia | Example: "Siéntate adelante para que no nos pillen en Uber" = Sit in front so we don't get caught in an Uber | Informal | Colombian context
Directing to major Bogotá highway | 'Coger' = to take (route) | Example: "Para ir al aeropuerto, coja la Autopista Norte" = To go to the airport, take Autopista Norte | Informal
Dedicated bike lanes in Colombian cities | Example: "Es más rápido ir por la cicloruta" = It's faster to go via the bike path | Informal
Short for 'bicicleta' | Common in bike-friendly cities | Example: "No me demoro, voy en bici" = I won't take long, I'm going by bike | Informal
